awd_titl_txt: SBE: Small: An optimization framework for prioritizing cyber-security mitigations for securing information technology infrastructure
awd_abstract_narration:
Our nation's information technology (IT) infrastructure is vulnerable to numerous security risks, including security vulnerabilities within the IT supply chain.  This research addresses the cyber-security risks and vulnerabilities that exist in the Federal IT infrastructure. It will provide new insights for prioritizing and deploying IT security mitigations in a budget-constrained environment. It will also develop tools that can be used by Federal decision-makers and other large organizations which make investments. These tools enable prioritizing, among numerous potential options, the cost-effective security implementations which reduce threats and secure IT infrastructure. 

The research will introduce new models that capture the key facets of prioritizing IT security mitigations. The new optimization models are formulated as mixed integer linear programming models, robust optimization models, and bi-level programming interdiction models. They capture adversarial attack paths, overlapping security mitigation capabilities, tradeoffs between multiple criteria, robustness to data uncertainties, and the impact of adaptive adversaries. Models with adaptive adversaries are a major focus, and therefore, the models explore a range of adversarial strategic sophistication. The methodological contributions include an analysis of the model features, performance guarantees associated with proposed approximation algorithms, new valid inequalities to improve the ability to solve the models, and new techniques to obtain solutions robust to uncertainty of the functions used in a model. The overall goal is to protect Federal IT infrastructure by identifying the right mix of security mitigations that is effective with respect to cost, threat reduction, and consequence mitigation.

por.por_cntn:
Our nation's information technology (IT) infrastructure is vulnerable to numerous security risks, including security vulnerabilities within the IT supply chain. This research addressed the cyber-security risks and vulnerabilities that exist in the Federal IT infrastructure. 

This research led to a deeper understanding of how to protect critical IT infrastructure using limited security resources by formulating, analyzing and solving a suite of optimization problems. The research introduced new optimization models that capture the key facets of prioritizing IT security mitigations. These new optimization models were formulated as mixed integer linear programming models, stochastic programming models, and bi-level programming network interdiction models. The models capture adversarial attack paths, overlapping security mitigation capabilities, tradeoffs between multiple criteria, and decision-making under uncertainty. Models with adaptive adversaries were a major focus, and therefore, the models explore a range of adversarial strategic sophistication from simple adversarial models where an adversary can select a single “best case” path to advanced models where an adversary has recourse and can change decisions based on defensive actions.

The research led to new methodological contributions in solving large-scale optimization problems. The theoretical contributions include an analysis of the model features, performance guarantees associated with proposed approximation algorithms, and new valid inequalities to improve the ability to solve the models. The computational contributions include the application of greedy algorithms and Benders branch-and-cut algorithms for identifying near-optimal and optimal solutions to the mixed integer and stochastic programming models in short amounts of computational times, a Lagrangian relaxation algorithm for solving a large-scale project interdiction problem with multiple adaptive adversaries, and new branch-and-cut algorithms for the problem of interdicting an attacker with an uncertain target. These contributions pushed forward the computational frontier of optimization-based infrastructure protection.

This project developed new models and algorithms for prioritizing and deploying IT security mitigations in a budget-constrained environment. The models enable prioritizing, among numerous potential options, a portfolio of cost-effective security implementations that reduce threats and secure IT infrastructure. The models and analysis provide important new insights into identifying the most critical components of a network to protect in an uncertain environment. Research results were disseminated widely through peer-reviewed publications, conference talks, and research seminars. The research results were disseminated to collaborative partners and stakeholders through collaboration meetings and transition to practice meetings as well as to the public through public talks, media appearances, and social media.
